Experts say that the high air exchange rate and wearing masks sharply reduce the risk of spreading the virus.

But if more people are riding the subway, it's harder for ventilation to lessen the risk of transmission.

See more. 

https://t.co/PAtFVYsKQn

The ventilation system pushes air across the train rather than down into floor vents. So someone standing between a person without a mask who sneezes or coughs and the ceiling vent could come into contact with aerosols. 
https://t.co/PAtFVYsKQn https://t.co/KlOVpYrkQQ

If viral particles slip past the system’s filters, they could circulate at least 3 times in the car over several minutes.

If someone sneezes, riders could be exposed to viral particles that don’t get filtered out — which is one reason why wearing masks is important. https://t.co/rNAl7cC9Kc

The ventilation helps fully replace air in the car with outside air about every 3 or 4 minutes.

Filters work to block viral particles, but some could slip past and get dispersed into trains.
https://t.co/PAtFVYsKQn https://t.co/Sygm453p3T

75% of the air in a subway car is recycled. It’s sucked into vents, cooled and filtered.

25% is pulled from the outside and combined with the existing air.

Here’s how air flow through this venting system helps limit viral particles from building up inside a car. https://t.co/Oye1S39GM4

Air flow is key in preventing the spread of the virus on subways, along with masks and social distancing. 

The subway’s ventilation system moves air within the train cars more efficiently than in restaurants and other indoor settings, experts say — but it's not perfect. https://t.co/YpiZQqzzP8

Subway ridership is way down in New York City — 20% of the city’s 5.5 million weekday riders are using the system. Many fear the confined spaces of subway cars will lead to coronavirus infections. 

We looked at how safe the air is on the subway. 
https://t.co/PAtFVYsKQn

But the altering of a classified document on a subject known to anger the president signifies a new development of the Trump era: the intelligence community’s willingness to change what it would otherwise say straightforwardly, so that it would not upset him.

Jared Kushner's role in the administration also created unease within the intelligence community. A former senior administration official recalled that Kushner “would have the Chinese ambassador and his minions wandering around the West Wing unescorted.”

One former senior administration official told @DraperRobert that President Trump would “show off about some of the stuff he thought was cool — the capabilities of different weapons systems,” to billionaires.

On his first full day in office, President Trump addressed an audience of agency employees at CIA headquarters, where he bragged about his inauguration speech and questioned the judgment of whoever had chosen to put so many columns in the lobby. Agency veterans were furious. https://t.co/2BW4jnc5UA

Under Trump, intelligence officials have been placed in the unusual position of being pressured to justify the importance of their work, protect their colleagues from political retribution and demonstrate fealty to a president, @DraperRobert reports.

.@DraperRobert spoke to 40 current and former intelligence officials, lawmakers and congressional staff, including 15 people who worked in or closely with the intelligence community during Trump’s presidency. https://t.co/CZEJti9Wa1 https://t.co/yQrXiacC8C

Here’s how epidemiologists think about uncertainty in the Covid-19 context, and how they’re using Bayes’s theorem to update and revise our understanding of the uncertainties and risks posed by the coronavirus: https://t.co/CotrgT7kut

“Much of the information that guides our behavior in the context of Covid-19 is probabilistic,” writes @sioroberts in @NYTScience. “Humans on their own, however, without a Bayesian model for a compass, are notoriously bad at fathoming individual risk.” https://t.co/CotrgT7kut https://t.co/hpedZB8wfk

Bayes’s theorem as applied to the Covid-19 antibodies test is expressed as a probability, “P” — with, say, “T” for a positive test result and “C” for the presence of Covid-19 antibodies https://t.co/CotrgT7kut https://t.co/oMBeIsy9l4

Take the scenario of Covid-19 antibodies testing, for instance. Running the numbers through the Bayesian gears, the theorem calculates what you really want to know: the probability that the test result is correct. https://t.co/CotrgT7kut https://t.co/q65tCXIFvJ

Known as Bayes’s theorem, the formula is a device for rationally updating our prior beliefs and uncertainties based on observed evidence. In other words, “As we learn more, our beliefs should change,” said Marc Lipsitch, an epidemiologist at Harvard. https://t.co/CotrgT7kut https://t.co/n5bGblFWoq

One mathematically simple yet conceptually powerful formula can help us evaluate various Covid-19 uncertainties — and perhaps more importantly, help us adjust our understanding of the uncertainties and risks as we learn more about the virus. https://t.co/CotrgT7kut

In the end, the U.S. death toll reached an estimated 675,000; San Francisco was one of the worst-hit cities.

"Masks turned into a political symbol," a medical historian said.

Read more on how they took a role in cultural wars a century ago. https://t.co/4hJ9zjO3VP

By the end of 1918, the flu’s death toll reached at least 244,681, mostly in the last 4 months, according to government statistics.

But opposition to masks continued: The "Anti-Mask League," which has seen renewed interest today, held its first meetings in January of 1919.

San Francisco’s mask ordinance expired after 4 weeks at noon on November 21, 1918. The spread had been halted. But a second wave was on the horizon.

By December, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors was again proposing a mask requirement. It was met with testy opposition. https://t.co/717kbVitAz

On Nov. 9, 1,000 people were arrested, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. City prisons swelled to standing room only.

At outdoor court sessions, jail terms of 8 hours to 10 days were given out. Those who could not pay $5 were jailed for 48 hours. https://t.co/jKxWOUojZs

Complaints mounted about masks shortly after the first order was passed — even after the flu killed an estimated 195,000 Americans in October 1918 alone.

The penalty for violators in San Francisco was $5 to $10, or 10 days’ imprisonment. https://t.co/lvUhLf9ax4

The first U.S. cases of the 1918 influenza pandemic came in March. By fall, 7 cities — San Francisco, Seattle, Oakland, Sacramento, Denver, Indianapolis and Pasadena, California — had mandatory mask laws.

San Francisco was at the forefront, becoming known as the “masked city.” https://t.co/UFyFR6Z3J2

Masks were called muzzles, germ shields and dirt traps. They gave people a “pig-like snout.”

Some snipped holes in their masks to smoke cigars. Others fastened them to dogs in mockery.

Bandits used them to rob banks.

There were calls to protest, like this one in California. https://t.co/T1AJExyccv

In 1918 and 1919, masks also stoked political division. Then, as now, medical authorities urged people to wear them to help slow the spread of disease. And then, as now, some people resisted.

Here's how that started — and what it looked like. https://t.co/QYHzGV33hM

Read more answers to key questions about holding elections in a crisis — and why a president can't cancel an election on their own. https://t.co/oUswyFZllD

𝐐. Is President Trump correct that voting by mail leads to fraud?

𝐀. No. Studies have shown that all forms of voting fraud are very rare in the U.S. A panel Trump established to investigate election corruption was disbanded in 2018 after it found no real evidence of fraud.

𝐐. Didn’t many states postpone their primary elections this year?

𝐀. Yes, states have broad autonomy to schedule and run their own primary elections.

16 states and 2 territories either delayed their presidential primaries or extended vote-by-mail deadlines.

𝐐. How likely is it that the U.S. election will be delayed?

𝐀. The House, which is controlled by Democrats; the Senate, which is controlled by Republicans; and President Trump would all have to agree.

To say that’s unlikely is an understatement.

𝐐. Can a president cancel or postpone an election by executive order?

𝐀. No. The date of the general election — the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November — is set by federal law and has been fixed since 1845.

It would take a change in federal law to move the date.

President Trump does not have the authority to move the date of a federal election.

And his claim that mail-in voting would make the election “inaccurate and fraudulent” is false.

Here's what to know. https://t.co/zkQR6h8A1J

In some countries, schools that reopened with similar guidelines have relaxed them as infections stayed low.

The U.S. is different: Some schools will try to reopen classrooms as infections in the area remain high.

See more of what schools may look like. https://t.co/NoOlga9knL

Schools are not planning to follow a traditional bell schedule. 

Instead, individual pods of students will travel through unidirectional hallways at specific times, including, in some cases, for pre-scheduled bathroom breaks. https://t.co/NoOlga9knL https://t.co/0LFgsY8Sqa

Desks may have plastic shields, in addition to being placed according to social distancing guidelines.

Some students could be learning online even while in a classroom in order to access more advanced material. https://t.co/NoOlga9knL https://t.co/SGdXuugjRf

In middle and high schools, students who normally move between classrooms during the day will remain in self-contained pods as much as possible.

That means schools will have to figure out another way to deliver an individualized curriculum.

Some schools will use X’s to show students where to sit for story time.

Teachers may also use clear face shields instead of masks: Seeing an adult’s mouth move helps children understand connections between spoken sounds and the written word — a key concept in early reading. https://t.co/lT7griplCP

Once students are inside, classrooms will also look very different.  

One goal is to keep children in self-contained pods that could be quarantined if someone tests positive, without affecting the rest of the school. https://t.co/NoOlga9knL https://t.co/MFK11XKym1

When students arrive at school, most will be checked to see if they are running a temperature or showing other symptoms.

If adults are dropping off children, they will likely remain behind a barrier. https://t.co/NoOlga9knL https://t.co/OxLReuDcPD

Schools in Marietta, Georgia, plan to spend $640,000 to hire 55 monitors to check students’ symptoms before they board buses.

Dundee, Michigan, expects to spend over $300,000 to add bus routes. https://t.co/NoOlga9knL https://t.co/wYGy8K9tTC

Changes at school will start as soon as students leave home: Bus rides won’t look the same.

A typical bus carries 54 children. With social distancing, it might be 8.

Some might use a zig-zag pattern and masks to allow more students on board. https://t.co/NoOlga9knL https://t.co/HVmVqUDI0F
How could schools reopen classrooms safely during the pandemic? Everything would need to look different, experts say, from kindergarten story time to high school math class. https://t.co/tuDXD6IR8w

Jezero might just be the key to finding out whether Martian life thrived long ago.

There’s only one way to find out – going there. 🚀https://t.co/LdjXdCPEfV

Part of NASA’s mission with Perseverance is to collect pieces of Mars rocks that a follow-up spacecraft will bring back to Earth. 

Scientists will be able to peer at the samples in exquisite detail for signs of past life. https://t.co/Z6kjmSiM2S

Jezero’s fine lake sediments could also have been a happy home for tiny Martians.

On Earth, layers of microbes can form at the bottom of a lake. If anything like that lived in Jezero, it could have left wavy patterns in the rocks similar to those found in Earth rocks. https://t.co/HBzsZ2yETC

Water is a requirement for life, and Jezero is one of hundreds of former lakes on Mars. 

What makes it special is the spot where a river flowed into Jezero 3.5 billion-or-so years ago. Scientists think they might find patterns in rocks that could have been the work of microbes. https://t.co/yagQ2hapOl

No one expects to find the Martian equivalent of dinosaur fossils, shark teeth or seashells in Jezero. 

If life existed on Mars, it likely resembled what existed in Earth’s earliest days — like single-cell microbes in oceans, lakes and rivers. https://t.co/LdjXdCPEfV https://t.co/JnPcSvXy0Z

After a tough selection process, Perseverance mission scientists narrowed the possible Mars landing sites to 3. Jezero made the cut.

And in 2018, the crater was officially chosen. https://t.co/LdjXdCPEfV https://t.co/C8X4BdiqJQ

6 years ago, scientists began debating where to send the rover, starting with more than 30 possible locations. 

For each, scientists presented their arguments in favor like lawyers laying out a case. Timothy Goudge, now at the University of Texas, became the champion for Jezero.

NASA’s Perseverance rover, expected to launch on July 30th, will try to land here in February. 

The rover will spend years exploring Jezero's river delta, making its way to the crater rim and looking for signs of ancient life.

So why Jezero? https://t.co/LdjXdCPEfV https://t.co/9FP3I8gNo3

✨ Is there life – tiny, microscopic, extinct life – on Mars? ✨ 

Jezero, a one-time lake on Mars, is the best place to look, scientists have decided. https://t.co/LdjXdCPEfV

In Arizona, Joe Biden had pockets of strength in cities like Phoenix and Tucson, but many areas elsewhere were particularly friendly for President Trump.

In Pennsylvania, Joe Biden was dominant in attracting donors not just in deep-blue Philadelphia, but also in suburbs. Another strong area was a college town: The dot in the middle is State College, home to Penn State.

Three of the 4 best ZIP codes for Joe Biden, in terms of the number of donors, were on Manhattan's Upper West Side.
